definition.en: An all-embracing term for all fields of natural sciences related to the planet Earth. It is occasionally used as a synonym for geology or geological sciences, but this usage is misleading because in its wider scope earth science may be considered to include such subjects as meteorology, physical oceanography, soil chemistry, and agronomy.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: A seismic method that involves monitoring artificially induced signals.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The science of the acquisition, processing, and analysis of seismic datasets measured and recorded with reference to a particular area of the Earth's surface, to evaluate the subsurface.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: Remotely sensed spectral imaging obtained from an airborne platform.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The use of multiple bands across the electromagnetic spectrum to create a dataset that contains many images of the same object, where each one of them is measured at a different wavelength. It includes multispectral imaging that typically captures three to fifteen spectral bands, and hyperspectral imaging that combines spectroscopy and digital photography to capture hundreds of wavelength bands.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011)
2) Wikipedia
3) Garini, Y and Tauber, E 2013, Spectral Imaging: Methods, Design, and Applications, in Biomedical Optical Imaging Technologies, Biological and Medical Physics, Biomedical Engineering, edited by R Liang: Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, doi.org/10.1007/978-3-642-28391-8_4.

definition.en: A discipline concerned with investigating the Earth from the surface to a depth of several kilometres, specifically aiming to meet the growing demands for natural resources and geo-energies, to respond to the effects of climate change, to provide critical data for civil engineers, and to forecast the effects of natural hazards.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition from https://erdw.ethz.ch/en/studies/master/applied-geophysics.html.

definition.en: A natural science concerned with the physical processes and physical properties of the Earth and its surrounding space environment, and the use of quantitative methods for their analysis. It includes several disciplines focusing on the study of the Earth's electrical, gravitational and magnetic fields and the propagation of elastic (seismic) waves within it.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Applied mineralogy is located at the intersection of natural sciences and engineering sciences/technology and deals with the entire line of raw material, from extraction/preparation to processing and disposal, i.e. the application of mineralogical information to understanding and solving problems encountered during exploration and mining, and during processing of ores, concentrates, smelter products, and related materials. It involves characterizing minerals and materials, and interpreting the data with respect to exploration, mineral processing, tailings disposal and treatment, hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, and refining.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Petruk, W 2000, Chapter 1: General principles of applied mineralogy, in Applied Mineralogy in the Mining Industry, edited by W Petruk: Amsterdam, Elsevier Science p. 1–26, doi.org/10.1016/B978-044450077-9/50003-1
2) Götze, J and Göbbels, M 2023, Introduction, in Introduction to Applied Mineralogy: Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, p. 1–2, doi.org/10.1007/978-3-662-64867-4_1.

definition.en: The scientific study of minerals, their formation, occurrence, physical and chemical properties, composition, and classification.

historyNote.none: Definition from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Archival science, or archival studies, is the study and theory of building and curating archives, i.e. collections of documents, recordings, photographs and various other materials in physical or digital formats, for the purpose of acquiring, evaluating, and accessing recorded materials.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The field of science concerned with the study of life in the universe and attempting to solve the mystery of how life emerged on Earth. This includes the search for life beyond Earth, studying environments that could support life as well as investigating interactions between planets and their stars and exploring how this could influence life. Astrobiology is very much an interdisciplinary endeavour encompassing a wide range of scientific fields such as, but not limited to; biology, astronomy, chemistry, geology, atmospheric science, oceanography, and even aeronautical engineering.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from www.space.com.

definition.en: The natural sciences that study celestial objects and the phenomena that occur in the cosmos. It uses mathematics, physics, and chemistry to explain their origin and their overall evolution. Objects of interest include planets, moons, stars, nebulae, galaxies, meteoroids, asteroids, and comets or, more generally, everything that originates beyond Earth's atmosphere.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the undifferentiated complex of rocks that underlies the rocks of interest in an area, i.e. the crust of the Earth below sedimentary deposits and regolith, extending downward to the Mohorovičić discontinuity. Basement geology may be self-referential in that it is also the study of defining what constitutes basement at regional and local scales, and whether geologically or economically defined.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et. al., 2011), Wikipedia and the Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: An Earth science concerned with the planet Earth and the rocks/materials of which it is made, the processes that act on these materials and by which these change over time, the products formed, to understand the history of the planet and its life forms since its origin, and including the study of physical forces that act on the Earth, the chemistry of its constituent materials, and the biology of its past inhabitants as revealed by fossils. Geology can also include the study of the solid features of any terrestrial planet or natural satellite such as Mars or the Moon. Modern geology significantly overlaps all other earth sciences, including hydrology and the atmospheric sciences, and so is treated as one major aspect of integrated Earth system science and planetary science.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (Neuendorf et. al., 2011, 5th edition revised) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: A geological method of studying sedimentary basins and their potential for energy/mineral commodities, by analysing the sediment fill itself (its composition, primary structures, and internal architecture) to synthesize the basin's geological history/evolution.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and the Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: A highly interdisciplinary field involving the integration of biology, geology and chemistry, and encompassing the study of the chemical, physical, geological and biological processes and reactions that govern the composition of the natural environment (including the biosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, pedosphere and the lithosphere).

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The study of the distribution and amounts of the chemical elements in minerals, ores, rocks, soils, water, the atmosphere on Earth and within solid bodies of the solar system, including the distribution, circulation and abundance of elements (and their ions and isotopes), molecules, minerals, rocks and fluids.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The interdisciplinary study of biology and geology, embracing interactions between the Earth's biosphere and geosphere (i.e. lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and cryosphere). It encompasses the biological aspects of geology, e.g. systematic paleontology, the study of organically influenced sedimentation, or the identification of a concealed rock unit by the type of plant growing at the surface above it.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et. al., 2011)
2) Yin, H, Xie, S, Qing, J, Yan, J and Luo, G 2008, Discussion on geobiology, biogeology and geobiofacies: Sci. China Ser. D-Earth Sci., v. 51, p. 1516–1524, doi:10.1007/s11430-008-0120-6.

definition.en: An interdisciplinary study of life sciences and Earth sciences, i.e. the field of scientific research that explores the interactions between the physical Earth and the biosphere to investigate the evolutionary interconnectedness of life and Earth — it deals with process (how organisms affect the Earth and vice versa), as well as history (how the Earth and life have changed together). There is considerable overlap with the fields of ecology, evolutionary biology, microbiology, paleontology, and particularly soil science and biogeochemistry. Geobiology applies the principles and methods of biology, geology and soil science to the study of the ancient history of the co-evolution of life and Earth as well as the role of life in the modern world. Geobiological studies tend to be focused on micro-organisms, and on the role that life plays in altering the chemical and physical environment of the pedosphere, which exists at the intersection of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and/or cryosphere. It differs from biogeochemistry in that the focus is on processes and organisms over space and time rather than on global chemical cycles.

historyNote.none:
Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from:
1) Wikipedia
2) Yin, H, Xie, S, Qing, J, Yan, J and Luo, G 2008, Discussion on geobiology, biogeology and geobiofacies: Sci. China Ser. D-Earth Sci., v. 51, p. 1516–1524), doi:10.1007/s11430-008-0120-6).

definition.en: The correlation and age determination of rocks through the use of fossils, i.e. the determination of approximate absolute ages from the distribution of fossil assemblages in strata and primarily based on a number of time scales that related absolute age to the established sequence of (primarily planktonic) fossil events.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from AAPG Wiki.

definition.en: The science of dating and determining the time sequence of events in the history of the Earth, i.e. the study of the relative or numerical/absolute age of rocks, minerals and fossils. Numerical age is the measurement of age in years ('numerical' is preferred to 'absolute' ages, as the latter typically have some amount of error and are inexact) whereas relative age, in contrast, is the approximate age of rocks, fossils or minerals made by determining the age of the material relative to the age of and relationships with other surrounding material.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et. al., 2011) and Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary.

definition.en: Boreheole (or well) logging is the practice of making a detailed record (a well log, report or graph) of the geological materials and formations penetrated by a borehole. The log may be based either on visual inspection of samples brought to the surface (geological logs) or on physical measurements made on these samples or by instruments lowered into the hole (geophysical logs). Some types of geophysical well logs can be done during any phase of a well's history: drilling, completing, producing, or abandoning. Logging is performed in boreholes drilled for the oil and gas, groundwater, mineral and geothermal exploration, as well as part of environmental, geotechnical or geological studies.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The acquisition of a continuous record as a function of depth, usually graphic and plotted to scale, of observations, analyses or measurements made on the geological materials of the section exposed in a borehole or of the sample (drillcore or cuttings) obtained from it.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Studies related to the identification of deep, subsurface geological sites that are suitable to act as reservoirs for the long-term storage of injected CO₂, to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions to the atmosphere.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The science and art of making maps and charts, and the specific use of digital technologies (mapping tools and software) to create seamless geographical displays of data as an image on a computer screen.

historyNote.none: Definition compiled by the Geological survey of western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: A professional engineering discipline that focuses on spatial information (i.e. information that has a location) to design, develop, and operate systems for collecting and analysing spatial information about the land, the oceans, natural resources, and man-made features.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Chemostratigraphy, or chemical stratigraphy, is the study of the chemical signatures and their variations within lithological sequences to determine stratigraphic relationships. It includes the element of stratigraphy that deals with chemical signals as recorded in the stratigraphic record to identify spatial–temporal variations in the concentration and distribution of particular elements and isotopes (e.g. carbonate cycles and isotope cycles).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of the history, composition, relative ages and distribution of strata, and the interpretation of strata to elucidate Earth's history. The comparison, or correlation, of separated strata can include study of their form, distribution, lithology, fossil content, geophysical and geochemical properties, relative or numerical/absolute age, and their interpretation in terms of environment or mode of origin, and geological history.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

definition.en: The branch of stratigraphy that deals with the age of strata and their time relations.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Climatology or climate science is the scientific study of Earth's climate, typically defined as weather conditions averaged over a period of at least 30 years. Climate concerns the atmospheric condition during an extended to indefinite period of time; weather is the condition of the atmosphere during a relative brief period of time and is studied by within the field of meteorology.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Climate change science is the study of changes in the statistical properties of the climate system that persists for several decades or longer — usually at least 30 years. In a broader sense, climate change science also includes previous long-term changes to Earth's climate. These statistical properties include averages, variability and extremes. Climate change may be due to natural processes, such as changes in the Sun’s radiation, volcanoes activity or internal variability in the climate system, or due to human influences such as changes in the composition of the atmosphere or land use caused by human activity (e.g. burning of fossil fuels, deforestation). In common usage, climate change is often used interchangeably to describe global warming — the ongoing increase in global average temperature — and its effects on Earth's climate system.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Coal geology includes the study of the sedimentation of coals and coal-bearing sequences; their stratigraphy, age and geographic distribution; their physical properties, including coal rank and quality, and the associated classification of coals; their hydrogeological characteristics; contained gases, and the contribution of coal deposits (amongst other rock types) to accumulations of oil and natural gas.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Thomas, L 2013, Coal Geology, Second Edition: John Wiley & Sons, Ltd, 444p., doi.10.1002/9781118385685.

definition.en: A branch of geology that focuses on the study of conventional, non-conventional and renewable natural resources used for energy production, i.e. including fossil fuels (like coal, oil, and natural gas), renewable energy resources (like wind, solar, and geothermal), and nuclear resources. This field involves understanding the formation, distribution, extraction, and environmental impacts of these energy resource.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/energy-geoscience.

definition.en: Collection management refers to the development, storage, and preservation of cultural and natural property, as well as objects of contemporary culture (including contemporary art, literature, technology, and documents) in museums, libraries, archives and private collections. The primary goal of collections management is to meet the needs of the individual collector or collecting institution's mission statement, while also ensuring the long-term safety and sustainability of the objects within the collector's care. Collections management consists primarily of the administrative responsibilities associated with collection development and maintenance (information, preservation, movement, documentation, exhibitions and access processes), and is closely related to collections care, that is the physical preservation for posterity of items in the collections.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Matassa, F 2018, Museum Collections Management, Facet Publishing, Cambridge University press, 258p., doi.10.29085/9781856048699
2) Wikipedia.

prefLabel.en: computational modelling and simulation in earth sciences

definition.en: A multidisciplinary field that combines geoscience with advanced mathematical modelling, simulation, numerical modelling, visualization and data analysis techniques. Computational geoscience uses large-scale, nonlinear models that couple multiple physical, chemical, and biological processes across various length and time scales to improve our understanding of the Earth system and its complexities, addressing geoscience grand challenges, and providing decision-support tools for geoscience policy makers and industry. The emergence of computation as a powerful tool for prediction and decision-making in the geosciences is driven by advances in the rapid expansion of our ability to instrument and observe the Earth, sustained improvements in computational models and solution methods for complex geoscience systems, and the relentless growth in computing power.

historyNote.none:
From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from adapted from:
1) https://link.springer.com/journal/10596
2) https://cse.umn.edu/esci/computational-geoscience.

definition.en: The application of modern information technology/computational systems to organize, preserve, and distribute geoscience data, and to facilitate and advance their analysis, i.e. the science and technology that develop and use data, software, and computing facilities in the cyberinfrastructure ecosystem to address the needs of geosciences and related branches of science and engineering.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Computed tomography (CT) is a method for imaging and analysing features in rock, mineral or soil specimens in three dimensions using energy attenuation of photons (X-ray tomography), neutrons (neutron tomography), ultrasonic waves (ultrasound tomography), or using magnetic resonance (magnetic resonance imaging). The detected data are used to reconstruct the internal distribution of materials.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Carlson, WD 2006, Three-dimensional imaging of earth and planetary materials: Earth and Planetary Science Letters, v. 249(3–4), p. 133–147, ISSN 0012-821X, doi.org/10.1016/j.epsl.2006.06.020.

definition.en: The non-destructive, three-dimensional characterization of earth and planetary materials that uses material-penetrating energy sources. Tomography methods in Earth Science include experiments in controlled laboratory settings such as computed tomography of rock samples or soils, and field experiments such as seismic tomography of the Solid Earth.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of conventional (carbonate and clastic) petroleum systems that contain hydrocarbon accumulations and are defined as those where buoyant forces keep hydrocarbons in place below the sealing caprocks and permit petroleum (oil and/or natural gas) to flow readily from reservoirs into wellbores; i.e. are accessible by standard oilfield techniques and typically do not require advanced drilling, completions, and reservoir stimulation methods. Studies of conventional reservoir include assessment of rock properties, particularly porosity, permeability and compressibility, and of the timing and mechanism of trap formation, as petroleum source rocks, reservoir rocks, impermeable caprocks/seals must form in a favourable sequence to allow accumulation in reservoir rocks (following petroleum generation in source rocks and its ensuing migration therefrom).

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: Study of the mode of origin and conditions of accumulation of hydrocarbons in the Earth's crust; their exploration, involving application of the techniques of geophysics, geochemistry, paleontology, stratigraphy, and tectonics; and their evaluation. It includes the assessment of petroleum systems and their composite parts: source, migration pathways, reservoir, seal, and method of entrapment.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Allaby, M 2008, A dictionary of Earth sciences, 4th edition: Oxford University Press, doi.10.1093/acref/9780199211944.001.00010.

definition.en: Studies related to the measurement of petrophysical properties in samples collected in the field or from drillcores.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The study of the physical and chemical properties of rocks in relation to their interaction with fluids. A major application of petrophysics is in studying reservoirs for the hydrocarbon industry (especially the distribution of the pore system and its contained hydrocarbons and water).

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: Core logging is the systematic recording and analysis of drillcores, to provide geological understanding of the materials penetrated by a borehole, and to assist in resource estimation. It employs different methods and techniques to characterize subsurface minerals, rocks and formations, as well as their geometry, structure and relationships relative to depth — by observation, measurements and analysis. Although a large proportion of drilling is carried out in the pursuit of mineral and energy resources, core logging is also a critical component of other investigations (e.g. stratigraphic, geotechnical, etc.).

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia from various sources.

definition.en: Spectral imaging (typically hyperspectral) of rock samples such as core.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The study of crystals, i.e. of homogeneous, solid bodies of chemical element, compound, or isomorphous mixture, having regularly repeating atomic arrangement that may be outwardly expressed by plane faces. It comprises studies of crystal growth, structure, physical properties and their classification by form. It includes optical crystallography (the branch dealing with the optical properties of crystals) and structural crystallography (the study of the internal arrangement and spacing of atoms and molecules composing crystalline solids).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The scientific study of the chemistry, crystal structure, and physical properties of minerals and mineralized artifacts.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The process of extracting and discovering patterns in large datasets involving methods at the intersection of machine learning, statistics, and database systems. Data mining is an interdisciplinary subfield of computer science and statistics with an overall goal of extracting information (with intelligent methods) from a dataset and transforming the information into a comprehensible structure for further use.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Data science is an interdisciplinary academic field that uses statistics, scientific computing, scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from noisy, structured, and unstructured data. Data management is the practice of collecting, organizing, protecting, and storing an organization’s data so it can be analysed for business decisions or provided to third parties.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Deep learning is a subset of machine learning methods that utilize neural networks for representation learning, i.e. simulate the complex decision-making power of the human brain. The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and is centered around stacking artificial neurons into layers and 'training' them to process data. The adjective 'deep' refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.'

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and IBM website.

definition.en: Artificial intelligence (AI), in its broadest sense, is intelligence exhibited by machines, particularly computer systems, i.e. the capability of machines/computers to imitate intelligent human behaviour without being explicitly programmed. By extension, a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and uses learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of annual growth rings of trees for dating of the recent past.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et. al., 2011).

definition.en: Descriptive mineralogy includes a description of the crystallographic, general physical and chemical characters of each mineral species, and provides an account of their mode of occurrence and characteristic associations. For minerals possessing an economic value, it includes a brief statement of their uses and industrial applications.

historyNote.none:
Definition from:
Mukherjee, S 2011, Descriptive mineralogy, in Applied Mineralogy: Springer, Dordrecht, p. 155–209, doi.org/10.1007/978-94-007-1162-4_7.

definition.en: Digital heritage is the use of digital media in the service of understanding and preserving cultural or natural heritage; more specifically, according to the Charter on the Preservation of Digital Heritage of UNESCO, digital heritage is defined as embracing 'cultural, educational, scientific and administrative resources, as well as technical, legal, medical and other kinds of information created digitally, or converted into digital form from existing analogue resources'. The main goal of the digitization of cultural and natural heritage is to enable the preservation and permanent access of current and future generations to culturally and scientific important objects at all scales.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Downhole, or borehole, geophysical surveys measure the physical properties of rocks along a subsurface drillhole.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: Studies related to and associated with the technological advancement of drilling operations, aimed at mitigating the drilling operational deficiencies and instabilities that could hinder operational performance activities and the economic part of drilling development with great effort to minimize their environmental footprint. It includes geoscience-related results obtained during the testing of improved or emerging technologies.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from: 
Teodoriu, C and Opeyemi, B 2021, An outlook of drilling technologies and innovations: present status and future trends: Energies, 14, 4499, doi.10.3390/en14154499.

definition.en: The study of fuels, metals and other materials of economic interest; it is concerned with the distribution, value and availability of resources, and the cost and benefits of their recovery.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from www.encyclopedia.com.

definition.en: The science of designing as well as safely and economically making a hole (also called a well or wellbore) from the surface through a rock (or formation) to target potential energy or mineral resources in the subsurface and facilitate the evaluation of the geological intervals penetrated.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Engineering that applies various branches of science in order to create new technology that aims to protect, maintain, extract, and establish sustainable natural resources.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Earth and Space Science Informatics (ESSI) encompasses a broad field that addresses data management practices, computation and analysis, and hardware and software infrastructure. It involves collaborative work to assess, design, implement, and promote practices and tools that enable effective data management, discovery, integration, and reuse for interdisciplinary work in Earth and space science (ESS) disciplines.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2021EA002108.

definition.en: The study of Earth as an integrated system, particularly the physical, chemical, biological and human interactions that determine the past, current and future states of the Earth. Earth System Science is the study of the interactions and interdependencies within and between the Earth’s various physical, chemical and biological “spheres” (lithosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, atmosphere, cryosphere), and the impacts that changes to any of these may have for the entire Earth System (including humans).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: A branch of biology concerning interactions among organisms and their biophysical environment, which includes both biotic and abiotic components.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The natural science that studies life and living organisms, including their physical structure, chemical processes, molecular interactions, physiological mechanisms, development and evolution.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: A discipline that investigates and promotes understanding of economic and policy issues associated with the production and use of mineral and energy commodities.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The use of geophysical methods to detect and image different electrical properties of the subsurface, by measuring naturally occurring (i.e. passive) or artificially introduced (i.e. active) voltage potentials, electrical currents, and/or electromagnetic fields. Subsurface electrical properties can be measured galvanically via direct electrode connection to the ground or inductively via electromagnetic field induction through the subsurface. The Electrical resistivity technique is used to determine the resistivity of subsurface materials, the Induced Polarization (IP) technique is used to measure the decay of voltage in the ground, and the Self-Potential (SP) technique looks for natural voltage sources underground.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from United States Environmental Protection Agency.

prefLabel.en: electrical and electromagnetic methods in geophysics

definition.en: Geophysical methods that involve the use of electrical and electromagnetic fields to study the subsurface properties of the Earth. These methods exploit the interaction between electromagnetic waves and the electrical conductivity, permittivity, and magnetic susceptibility of subsurface materials.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from https://geologyscience.com/geology-branches/.

definition.en: The use of geophysical methods to detect and image the electrical properties of the subsurface by inducing electromagnetic (EM) energy within the subsurface (i.e. propagation of electromagnetic fields composed of an alternating electric intensity and magnetizing force) and measuring the response of earth materials.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from United States Environmental Protection Agency.

definition.en: The measurement and modelling of the elevation of geographic locations, i.e. of the height above or below a fixed reference point, most commonly a reference geoid (a mathematical model of the Earth's sea level as an equipotential gravitational surface).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The science of measuring and representing the geometry (size and shape) of the Earth and the precise location of points on its surface; it includes the determination of the gravitational field of the Earth and the study of temporal variations such as Earth tides, polar motion, and rotation of the Earth.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The search for deposits of useful fossil fuels and energy resources. It includes multidisciplinary approaches, including geological studies, remote sensing, photogeology, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and below ground investigations.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The application of geology to engineering study for the purpose of assuring that the geological factors regarding the location, design, construction, operation and maintenance of engineering works are recognized and accounted for. Engineering geologists provide geological and geotechnical recommendations, analysis, and design associated with human development and various types of structures. The realm of the engineering geologist is essentially in the area of Earth-structure interactions, or investigation of how the Earth or Earth processes impact human-made structures and human activities.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: A professional engineering discipline related to environmental science that encompasses broad scientific topics like chemistry, biology, ecology, geology, hydraulics, hydrology, microbiology, and mathematics to create solutions that will protect and also improve the health of living organisms and improve the quality of the environment.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The practice of using natural science, mathematics, and the (engineering) design process to solve technical problems, increase efficiency and productivity, and improve systems. More specifically, 'the creative application of scientific principles to design or develop structures, machines, apparatus, or manufacturing processes, or works utilizing them singly or in combination; or to construct or operate the same with full cognizance of their design; or to forecast their behaviour under specific operating conditions; all as respects an intended function, economics of operation and safety to life and property' (American Engineers' Council for Professional Development).

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the effect on humans (and life in general) of the distribution and interrelations of the chemical elements and radioactivity among surficial rocks, water, air, and biota.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: An interdisciplinary academic field that integrates physical, biological and information sciences to the study of the environment, and the solution of environmental problems. It specifically addresses: (1) social and political decision making and policy setting relative to the environment or environmental ethics, (2) the planning and management of natural and human resources with an emphasis on the social and political aspects, and (3) legal and regulatory aspects of environmental protection activities carried out by the government under its powers.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Experimental mineralogy and petrology are the Earth science disciplines that model or simulate mineralogical, petrological, and geochemical processes within the laboratory in order to understand the physical and chemical properties of minerals, rocks, melts, and fluids and their interactions.

historyNote.none:
Definition from:
Geiger, CA and Kawamoto, T 2017, Experimental Mineralogy and Petrology, Encyclopedia of Geochemistry, Encyclopedia of Earth Sciences Series, edited by W White: Springer, Cham, doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-39193-9_311-2.

definition.en: A discipline that employs high-pressure, high-temperature apparatus to investigate the geochemistry and phase relations of natural or synthetic materials at elevated pressures and temperatures. Experiments are particularly useful for investigating rocks of the lower crust and upper mantle that rarely survive the journey to the surface in pristine condition. They are also one of the prime sources of information about completely inaccessible rocks, such as those in the Earth's lower mantle and in the mantles of the other terrestrial planets and the Moon. The work of experimental petrologists has laid a foundation on which modern understanding of igneous and metamorphic processes has been built.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: That branch of geology dealing with the origin, occurrence, structure, and history of rocks, including the conditions under which they form. Petrology is broader in scope than petrography.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Geochemistry that is specifically focused on identification of mineralization, its dispersion haloes, alteration patterns and distribution. It specifically focuses on the enrichment or depletion of certain elements (including pathfinders) having a genetic affinity to the target mineralization. Exploration geochemistry is typical of exploration stages aiming at locating mineral deposits but also applies to the near-mine exploration conducted to further locate and delineate resources.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from: 
Moon, C 2021, Exploration Geochemistry, in Encyclopedia of Geology (Second Edition), edited by D Alderton and SA Elias: Academic Press, p. 209–218, doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-08-102908-4.00017-5.

definition.en: A planetary science discipline concerned with the geology of celestial bodies such as the planets and their moons, asteroids, comets, and meteorites, i.e. a science that applies principles and techniques of geology, geochemistry, and geophysics to the study of the nature, origin, and history of the condensed matter and gases in the solar system and beyond. It includes a) remote-sensing observations and in situ manned exploration of other planetary bodies, such as the Moon and Mars, Venus, Mercury, and 'earthlike' or 'rocky' satellite moons of the giant planets; b) the study of the chemistry, mineralogy (cosmic mineralogy), and history of objects that occur on the Earth but are of known or possible extraterrestrial origin (such as meteorites and tektites) or that are returned to the Earth (such as lunar samples); and c) the study of the effects of extraterrestrial processes (such as meteorite impact, solar energy changes, and tides) on the Earth in the present and past.

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et. al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Analysis of the chemical and physical properties of fluids extracted from rocks and geological materials in the subsurface.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The study of the composition, stratigraphy and petrology of liquids and/or gases contained within tiny (usually in the order of micrometres) cavities formed either by the entrapment in crystal irregularities of fluids from which the mineral/rock crystallized, or by any process after the crystallization of the host mineral is essentially complete (e.g. healing of fractures within a crystal).

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of tiny encapsulations of fluids that trap oil, gas, water and solid phases in minerals and rocks to determine parameters such as temperature, pressure, salinity, density and depth of trapping — thereby providing direct information about the conditions of formation. In the case of hydrocarbon exploration, these studies are conducted to assess the fluid history of the rock/sedimentary basin and the prevailing thermal conditions, to determine whether oil and gas are likely to be found at a particular location, as well as the source and type of hydrocarbon present.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The study of trace evidence provided by Earth materials that is used to answer questions raised by the legal system, specifically the potential to link a suspect to a particular crime or a particular crime scene.

historyNote.none: Definition from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Functional morphology is an interpretative subdiscipline of paleobiology, and is the study of the form, structure and function of organisms or parts of organisms in terms of the biological roles that they play (i.e. function and behaviour).

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Cowen, R 1979, Morphology, functional: in Paleontology, Encyclopedia of Earth Science; Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, doi:10.1007/3-540-31078-9_89.

definition.en: A branch of paleontology that deals with the form and structure of organisms based on their fossil remains; especially a study of the forms, relations, and phylogenetic development of biological structures apart from their functions.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The science and study of natural and artificial gemstones, including their source, description, geology, origin, identification, grading and appraisal.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The empirical investigation of the principles that control mineral formation in the geological environment, including mineral paragenesis and the physical and chemical parameters of formation and alteration (mineral ontogenesis); the quantitative geothermometric, geobarometric, and chemical studies of mineral-forming systems; and experimental modelling of crystal growth in the laboratory.

historyNote.none:
Definition from: 
Wenk H-R and Bulakh A, 2004, Mineral genesis: in Minerals: Their Constitution and Origin, Cambridge University Press, p. 276–287.

definition.en: A multi-disciplinary approach that uses the techniques and subject matter of geography, geology, geophysics and other Earth sciences to examine topics which inform archeological and chronological knowledge and thought. Geoarcheologists study the natural physical processes that affect archeological sites such as geomorphology, the formation of sites through geological processes and the effects on buried sites and artifacts post-deposition.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of human cultures through the recovery and analysis of their material relics.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Geochemical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geochemistry.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The practice of protecting and managing sites and landscapes which have value for their geology or geomorphology. The identification (cf. geoheritage) and conservation of these geological sites is through government agencies and local geological societies. The designation of these sites is done through an analysis of the site, and the production of proper management infrastructure. The principles of geoconservation are to create a means of protection for the sites and assess their value to the geological and wider community. Typically the conservation of geodiversity at a site or within a landscape takes place alongside that of biodiversity.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Land-use and environmental planning involves the regulation and commitment of land-use, as to how the landscape is used (whether for food production, forestry, nature conservation, water storage, urban development, mining, etc.), to ensure the most efficient, effective and beneficial management and utilization of resources, and to provide optimal environmental and social outcomes.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: A subfield of geophysics dealing with the forces and processes of the interior of the Earth. It applies physics, chemistry and mathematics to the understanding of how mantle convection leads to plate tectonics and geological phenomena such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting and so on. It also attempts to probe the internal activities of the Earth by measuring magnetic fields, gravity, and seismic waves, as well as the mineralogy of rocks and their isotopic composition.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The branch of ethics that considers the interaction of human activity with the physical world and with the practice of the Earth Sciences. It comprises scientific research and philosophical reflection on the values governing human behaviours wherever they interact with the Earth system, including the ethical, social, and cultural implications of the activities of geoscientists when conducting scientific and technological research and practice.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Geographic Information Science (GIScience) is the basic research field that seeks to redefine geographic concepts and their use in the context of geographic information systems. GIScience also examines the impacts of GIS on individuals and society, and the influences of society on GIS. GIScience re-examines some of the most fundamental themes in traditional spatially oriented fields such as geography, cartography, and geodesy, while incorporating more recent developments in cognitive and information science

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Wikipedia
2) ISO/TR 19122:2004(en) - Geographic information / Geomatics.

definition.en: The study of adverse geological conditions capable of causing widespread damage or loss of property and life. These hazards are geological and environmental conditions and involve long-term or short-term geological processes. Geohazards can be relatively small features (e.g. geyser) but can also attain huge dimensions (e.g. submarine or surface landslide) and affect local and regional socio-economics to a large extent (e.g. tsunamis, volcanic eruptions).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The identification of global, national, state-wide, or local features of geology (such as igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary, stratigraphic, structural, geochemical, mineralogical, paleontological, geomorphical, pedological, and hydrological attributes) that are: (a) intrinsically important or culturally important sites; (b) offer information or insights into the formation or evolution of the Earth, or into the history of science, or (c) that can be used for research, teaching, or reference. Geoheritage is inextricably linked to geoconservation, for the preservation of these sites for posterity.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Brocx, M and Semeniuk, V 2007, Geoheritage and geoconservation — history, definition, scope and scale: Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia, v. 90, p. 53–87.

definition.en: Collectively, the study of practices, items and places designated as significant, including the investigation and interpretation of past human events (history), the identification, conservation and presentation of significant places, processes and items (heritage), and the study of human cultures through recovered artefacts or relics (archeology). Although history and archeology imply the interpretation of human culture, heritage and museum studies can be applied to concepts of both natural (abiotic or biotic) or cultural significance.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: Geoinformatics data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geoinformatics.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: The process of making observations in the field, as well as collecting and studying samples of Earth's materials to understand the geology of an area, and more specifically to produce a diagram, drawing, or other graphical representation of the area in question, by means of signs and/or symbols and with the means of orientation indicated, so that the relative position and size of each feature on the map corresponds to its correct geographical situation according to a definite and established scale and projection.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia

definition.en: The applied science of creating computerized representations of portions of the Earth’s subsurface based on geophysical and geological observations made on and below the Earth surface.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from https://courses.lumenlearning.com/geo/chapter/geologic-modelling/.

definition.en: The developing of tools that promote geoscience data integration and synthesis, and also facilitate quantitative cross-disciplinary access to data.

historyNote.none:
From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from:
Ferrini, V, Carbotte, S, Ryan, W and Chan, S 2013, Geoscience data visualization and analysis using GeoMapApp: EGU General Assembly 2013, 7–12 April, 2013, Vienna, Austria, EGU2013-6699.

definition.en: Geological data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geology.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: Geomatic engineering data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geomatics engineering.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: The discipline concerned with the collection, distribution, storage, analysis, processing, presentation of geographic data or geographic information, as well as the products, services and tools involved in the collection, integration and management of geographic (geospatial) data.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Wikipedia
2) ISO/TR 19122:2004(en) - Geographic information / Geomatics.

definition.en: A branch at the intersection of geology and engineering that embraces the fundamentals of structural geology and a knowledge of the response, or strain, of earth materials (soil and rocks) to deformation or changes caused by the application of stress and/or strain energy, as well as the application of such studies to solve engineering problems in the design of engineering works.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The practice of combining geology or geostatistics with extractive metallurgy, to create a spatially or geologically based predictive model to optimize the efficiency of mineral processing plants. Geometallurgy specifically maps the 3D variability in petrophysical and mineralogical properties of an entire orebody, to define domains that require different mining and metallurgical processing techniques, to maximize recovery of the saleable product at minimum cost.

historyNote.none: Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia (partly adapted from Wikipedia).

definition.en: Studies related to the process of extracting metallic or non-metallic mineral deposits from the Earth. The term may also include the preliminary treatment of extracted materials, e.g. cleaning or sizing.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The scientific study of the general configuration of the Earth's surface, i.e. of the origin and evolution of topographic and bathymetric features created by physical, chemical or biological processes operating at or near the Earth's surface. Specifically studies dealing with the classification, description, nature, origin, processes, and development of present landforms and their relationships to underlying structures, and of the history of geological changes as recorded by these surface features. Geomorphology overlaps in meaning with physiography, with 'physiography' commonly regarded as a more descriptive and 'geomorphology' as a more interpretative study of landforms.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The branch of natural science which deals with the classification, form, processes, extent and patterns of natural phenomena in the natural environment such as the atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and geosphere. It differs chiefly from geology in that it considers conditions of the Earth primarily over shorter time scales (e.g. Quaternary and/or modern rates). It is more inclusive than geomorphology, dealing not only with landforms but also climate, oceans, atmosphere, soils, geologic processes, natural resources, and the biogeographical distribution of animal and plant life.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of fluid dynamics of naturally occurring flows, such as lava flows, oceans, and planetary atmospheres, on Earth and other planets.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The applied science of creating computerized representations of the Earth based on geophysical and geological observations and their interpretation. Geophysical models are a simplified concept and/or visualization of how one or more physical properties are distributed within the Earth. They are generally an object, a halfspace, 1D (layered earth), 2D, or 3D.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from multiple sources.

definition.en: Geophysical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geophysics.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: A variety of practices that transmit scientific ideas, methods, knowledge, and research to non-expert audiences in an accessible, understandable, or useful way, with a particular focus on subjects related to Earth's physical features, processes, and systems.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: The systematic identification, analysis, planning, and implementation of actions designed to influence stakeholders. This process identifies the needs of key groups and ensures those needs are met.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from the Association for Project Management (www.apm.org.uk).

definition.en: Also known as Earth science education, it is the study of Earth's physical features, processes, and systems, as well as the natural and human-induced events that shape it. It encompasses a wide range of disciplines, including geology, oceanography, meteorology, climatology, environmental science, and more. Geoscience education plays a crucial role in fostering scientific literacy, environmental awareness, and sustainable development, as well as in preparing future generations of geoscientists, policymakers, educators, and citizens.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

prefLabel.en: geospatial information systems and geospatial data modelling

definition.en: The application of geographic information systems (GIS), i.e. an integrated computer hardware and software, to store, manage, analyse, edit, output, visualize and model geographic data.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: A branch of statistics focusing on spatial or spatiotemporal datasets, developed originally to predict probability distributions of ore grades for mining operations, but now applied also in petroleum geology, hydrogeology, hydrology, meteorology, oceanography, geochemistry, geometallurgy, geography, forestry, environmental control, landscape ecology, soil science and agriculture.

historyNote.none: Definition from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The development and application of mathematical methods and principles to process geoscientific data for geological feature imaging or for understanding (modelling) geological processes, from the atomic to planetary scale, across the entire spectrum of geoscientific disciplines.

historyNote.none: Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: Engineering applied to the capture and storage of materials (commonly liquids and gases, and especially greenhouse gases) or energy (commonly gas or heat) in the subsurface of the Earth.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from University of New south Wales website and Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: A field at the intersection of geology and engineering dealing with the study of the engineering behaviours of earth materials to address engineering problems. It uses soil and rock mechanics for practical applications in, amongst other disciplines, mining engineering, petroleum engineering, coastal engineering, and onshore/offshore construction.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the accessible thermal energy stored within the Earth's crust, in order to access and extract it. It includes studies of related geological systems and the methods, materials and operations used in the production of energy.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: A subdiscipline of geophysics that studies the thermal state of the interior of the solid Earth and of the thermal properties of Earth materials. Components of geothermal research are temperature distribution within the Earth, terrestrial heat flow, heat generation, thermal properties of Earth materials, volcanology, geothermal energy, hydrocarbon formation, fluid flow, and permafrost. Cf. temperature studies.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of heatflow and radioactive activity within the Earth.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: Tourism that sustains or enhances the distinctive geographical character of a place — its environment, heritage, aesthetics, culture, and the well-being of its residents​.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition from the Australian Geoscience Council.

definition.en: The scientific discipline concerned with all aspects of ice and solid water on landmasses. It deals with the structure and properties of glaciers and ice sheets, their physical properties, formation and distribution, the dynamics of ice flow, and the interactions of ice accumulation with climate.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Grade control is the process aiming to maximize the value of ore mined and fed into the mill. This is commonly achieved by systematic, closely-spaced drilling to check the quality and grade of the ore while mining is underway. Drillhole data, other sampling data and geological mapping can all be used to delineate ore for mining purposes, thus ‘controlling the grade’ of feedstock to the mill.

historyNote.none: Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: The study of variations (anomalies) in the Earth's gravity field via measurements of the spatial gradient of gravitational acceleration.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The measure of changes in gravity due to variations in the density of the rocks to remotely map the distribution of different rock types and the structure of rocks in the Earth's subsurface.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Spectral imaging obtained in the field or at a mine site, especially using portable devices (e.g. pXRF); applications include characterization of outcrops and materials, mine wall face mapping, and ore grade classification.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

prefLabel.en: heritage, archive and museum studies not elsewhere classified

definition.en: Heritage, archive and museum studies not otherwise described by other sub-categories of heritage, archive and museum studies.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: Heritage conservation seeks to sustain the values of heritage (including both natural and cultural heritage) landscapes, places and objects, individually and collectively, so that the community and visitors can continue to appreciate, experience and learn from them and about them, and so that they can be passed on to future generations. More specifically, this field refers to the more practical or applied aspects of site or object restoration, preventative activities, and/or remedial treatments.

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from New South Wales Heritage Office's 'Interpreting Heritage places and items: guidelines'.

prefLabel.en: heritage, archive and museum studies not elsewhere classified

definition.en: Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from NSW Heritage Office's 'Interpreting Heritage places and items: guidelines'.

definition.en: The study of collections, their heritage values and the ways of presenting their significance (interpretation) as a 'means of communicating ideas and feelings which help people enrich their understanding and appreciation of their world and their role within it' (Australian Heritage Commission).

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from NSW Heritage Office's 'Interpreting Heritage places and items: guidelines'.

prefLabel.en: heritage tourism, visitor and audience studies

definition.en: Heritage tourism is a form of non-business travel whereby tourists engage with the heritage, tangible and intangible, moveable and immovable, abstract or concrete, natural or cultural, of a region through activities, experiences, and purchases which facilitate a connection to the people, objects, and places of the past (including geological sites) associated with the locations being visited. Studies associated with this field refer to the management of such sites, the evaluation of the impact of visitors and the assessment of tourist satisfaction and emotional experiences during the visit.

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The branch of geology concerned with the reconstruction and comprehension of the geological history of the Earth, i.e. the evolution of the Earth and its life forms from its origins to the present day. This discipline examines the vastness of geological time, measured in billions of years, and investigates changes in the Earth (gradual and sudden) over this deep time. It focuses on geological processes, such as plate tectonics, that have changed the Earth's surface and subsurface over time and the use of methods including stratigraphy, structural geology, paleontology, and sedimentology to tell the sequence of these events. It also focuses on the evolution of life during different time periods in the geologic time scale. Not to be confused with history of geology.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: That branch of the history of science that documents the development of geological knowledge, including the history of observations of geological features, the history of theories to explain their origin, and the history of the organization and development of geological institutions and societies. The biographical study of geologists is included. Not to be confused with historical geology.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The chemistry of ground and surface waters, particularly the relationships between the chemical characteristics and quality of waters and the areal and regional geology. On a broader scale, the science that uses the tools and principles of chemistry to explain the mechanisms behind major geological systems such as the Earth's crust and its oceans.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The area of geology that deals with the distribution and movement of subsurface water (i.e. groundwater) in the soil and rocks of the Earth's crust, and with related geological aspects of surface waters.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the fossilized tracks, trails, burrows and excavations made by animals and more broadly the study of bioturbation, which is the reworking of sediment by animals. Ichnofossils or trace fossils are used to interpret paleoecological aspects of sedimentary environments.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Gingras, MK 2021, Ichnology, in Encyclopedia of Geology (Second Edition), edited by D Alderton and SA Elias: Academic Press, p. 669–680, doi.10.1016/B978-0-08-102908-4.00197-1.

definition.en: The scientific study of life in the geological past through the analysis of fossils, including those of microscopic size, and of traces representing preserved behaviour, preserved in rocks. It is concerned with all aspects of the biology of ancient life forms: their shape and structure, evolutionary patterns, taxonomic relationships with each other and with modern living species, geographic distribution, and interrelationships with the environment.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from https://www.britannica.com/science/paleontology.

definition.en: The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of igneous rocks, i.e. those that are formed from magma. It relies heavily on the use of chemistry, chemical methods, and phase diagrams.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Information management (IM) is the appropriate and optimized capture, storage, retrieval, and use of information. It may be personal information management or organizational. Information management for organizations concerns a cycle of organizational activity: the acquisition of information from one or more sources, the custodianship and the distribution of that information to those who need it, and its ultimate disposal through archiving or deletion and extraction.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Information and computing (or computer) science (ICS) or computer and information science (CIS) (or sciences) is a field that emphasizes both computing and informatics, upholding the strong association between the fields of information sciences and computer sciences and treating computers as a tool rather than a field. Information science is primarily concerned with gathering, storing, disseminating, sharing and protecting any and all forms of information — it is a broad field, covering a myriad of different areas but is often referenced alongside computer science because of the incredibly useful nature of computers and computer programs in helping those studying and doing research in the field, particularly in helping to analyse data and in spotting patterns too broad for a human to intuitively perceive.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: An information system (IS) is a formal, integrated set of components for the collection, storage and processing of data, aimed at providing information, contributing to knowledge and delivering digital products that facilitate decision-making.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.
