definition.en: The broader field for the study of the chemistry of inorganic rocks, minerals, and other Earth materials that are not currently or once living.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The part of cultural heritage that deals with items that have no physical existence, such as past and current traditions or living expressions inherited from our ancestors and passed on to our descendants (e.g. oral traditions, performing arts, social practices, rituals, festive events), knowledge and practices concerning nature and the universe, or the knowledge and skills to produce traditional crafts.

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from UNESCO.

definition.en: The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of organisms of the 'invertebrate' phyla, i.e. of those animals that lack notochords (non-vertebrates).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from https://journals.ku.edu/InvertebratePaleo and https://www.floridamuseum.ufl.edu/invertpaleo/.

definition.en: Spectral imaging and mapping obtained under controlled laboratory conditions, e.g. for the qualitative and quantitative mineral identification and phase relationships.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: The study of the complete chemical composition of whole rocks, considering the main and trace elements, but also isotopes.

historyNote.none:
Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from:
Alexandre, P 2021, Lithogeochemistry, in Practical Geochemistry, Springer Textbooks in Earth Sciences, Geography and Environment, Springer, Cham, doi:10.1007/978-3-030-72453-5_3.

definition.en: The element of stratigraphy that deals with the description and systematic organization of the rocks of the Earth's crust into distinctive named units based on the lithological character of the rocks and their stratigraphic relations. In the petroleum industry, lithostratigraphy specifically refers to the study and correlation of strata to elucidate Earth's history on the basis of their lithology or the nature of the well log response, mineral content, grain size, texture, and colour of rocks.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011) and Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary.

definition.en: A comprehensive study of the geological and geographical features of a subdivision of or area within a region (in this context defined as an area of land that has common natural features).

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia

definition.en: Machine learning (ML) is the field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalize to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and MITSloan website.

definition.en: The study of the Earth's magnetic field via non-invasive geophysical methods which measure perturbations in the Earth’s magnetic field caused by magnetic minerals in crustal rocks, specifically to image anomalies caused by source bodies within the subsurface.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of physical phenomena associated with moving electricity in conductive rocks or the permanent magnetic effects of naturally magnetic rocks, and the study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The element of stratigraphy that deals with the magnetic characteristics of rock units. Specifically the geophysical correlation technique used to date sedimentary rocks lacking fossils and volcanic sequences by collecting oriented samples at measured intervals throughout a section and measuring the characteristic remanent magnetization.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Magnetotellurics (MT) is a passive geophysical method used to infer the Earth's subsurface electrical resistivity/conductivity from measurements of natural variations of geomagnetic and geoelectric field at the Earth's surface, i.e. the use of natural electromagnetic signals to image subsurface electrical conductivity structure through electromagnetic induction.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Wikipedia
2) Unsworth, M 2007, Magnetotellurics, in Encyclopedia of Geomagnetism and Paleomagnetism, edited by D Gubbins and E Herrero-Bervera: Springer, Dordrecht, doi.10.1007/978-1-4020-4423-6_207.

definition.en: Maritime archeology (also known as marine archeology) is a discipline of archeology that specifically studies human interaction with the sea, lakes and rivers through the study of associated physical remains, be they vessels, shore-side facilities, port-related structures, cargoes, human remains and submerged landscapes.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The technical aspects related to the protection and care of materials to avoid their physical deterioration while actively ensuring their preservation for posterity.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020).

definition.en: An interdisciplinary scientific field studying the influence of natural geological factors on human and animal health. Broadly, medical geology studies exposure to or deficiency of trace elements and minerals (the distribution of trace elements as related to nutrition, or the geographic patterns of disease); inhalation of ambient and anthropogenic mineral dusts and volcanic emissions; transportation, modification and concentration of organic compounds; the occurrence of toxic elements in unusual quantities in parts of the Earth's crust; and exposure to radionuclides, microbes and pathogens.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

definition.en: The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of metamorphic rocks, i.e. those derived from the transformation of existing rocks into new types. It relies heavily on the use of chemistry, chemical methods, and phase diagrams.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The systematic study of fossil microbialites and other evidence of/for microbes and microbially influenced features in the geological record, focussing on their morphology, classification, and environmental and biostratigraphic significance. Microbial paleobiology commonly intersects with disciplines such as geobiology, astrobiology and biostratigraphy, and is commonly employed in studies concerned with the origins of life on Earth.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: The application of geological theory to warfare and the peacetime practices of the military. Military geologists are used for terrain analysis (geomorphology, soil science), engineering (building of roads and airfields), and the identification of resources (e.g. water supply or construction materials), and to research the effects of military practices on Earth's and planets' geology. The peacetime application of military geology includes the building of infrastructure, typically during local emergencies or foreign peacekeeping deployments.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

definition.en: The study of the chemical composition of minerals, i.e. of naturally occurring inorganic element or compound with a defined chemical composition and crystal structure, i.e. having a periodically repeating arrangement of atoms and characteristic chemical composition, resulting in distinctive physical properties. It includes the analysis of the major, minor, trace and isotope elemental composition of a mineral, as well as the bonding of these elements in the mineral’s crystal structure.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Studies related to the search for deposits of useful minerals. It may include geological reconnaissance, geological mapping, remote sensing analysis, geophysical and geochemical methods, and both surface and subsurface (e.g. drilling and underground) investigations. Also studies to establish the nature of a known mineral deposit, in preparatory to development and exploitation; in this sense exploration goes beyond discovery, and is a broader term than prospecting.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of concentrations of inorganic, naturally occurring, typically solid, typically non-renewable materials that are of intrinsic economic interest in or on the Earth's crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction. It includes the study of mineral systems, i.e. the combination of geological processes that are required to form and preserve an ore deposit. Also included is the characterization of orebodies (e.g. quantification of physical properties and chemical properties, and delineation of volumes, grades and geometry), and of limitations to the development and exploitation of mineral occurrences.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Understanding the combination of geologic processes that are required to form and preserve ore deposits at all scales. It recognises seven critical geological processes: source of mineralizing fluid, source of metals, fluid pathway, thermal gradient, energy source, structural focusing of fluids, and chemical or physical trap for metal precipitation.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) McCuaig, TC, Beresford, S and Hronsky, J 2010, Translating the mineral systems approach into an effective exploration targeting system: Ore Geology Reviews, v. 38, p. 128–138.
2) Wyborn, LAI, Heinrich, CA and Jaques, AL 1994, Australian Proterozoic mineral systems: Essential ingredients and mappable criteria: Proceedings of the Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Annual Conference, Darwin, 5–9 August 1994, p. 109–115.

definition.en: The application of molecular analytical techniques to fossil or subfossil material in order to test for the presence of original biomolecules. These molecules may be proteins, DNA, carbohydrates or lipids, or their diagenetic products.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Schweitzer, MH 2004, Molecular paleontology: some current advances and problems: Annales de Paléontologie, v. 90(2), p. 81–102, doi:10.1016/j.annpal.2004.02.001.

definition.en: The study of natural phenomena that might have a negative effect on humans or the environment, specifically hazards encompassing geological and meteorological phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, wildfires, cyclonic storms, floods, droughts, avalanches and landslides, as well as phenomena such as natural radioactivity.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the post-Miocene structures and structural history of the Earth's crust.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The branch of geology dealing with the broad architecture of the outer part of the Earth, i.e. the regional assembling of structural or deformational features, a study of their mutual relations, origin and historical evolution. It is closely related to structural geology, with which the distinctions are blurred, but tectonics generally deals with larger features.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The branch of isotope geochemistry focusing on non-radiogenic (or stable) isotope systems, i.e. those where a nuclide is not known to undergo radioactive decay.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The determination of the relative and absolute concentrations of the elements and their isotopes in the Earth and on Earth's surface.

historyNote.none:
From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from:
Kendall, C and Caldwell, EA 1998, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Isotope Geochemistry, in Isotope Tracers in Catchment Hydrology, edited by C Kendall and JJ McDonnell: Amsterdam, Elsevier Science, p. 51–86.

definition.en: The branch of geochronology / isotope geochemistry focusing on non-radiogenic (or stable) isotope systems, i.e. those where a nuclide is not known to undergo radioactive decay, to determine the numerical age of suitable geological materials.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The application of natural variations in the relative abundances of isotopes of various elements, measured by isotope-ratio mass spectrometry, to reveal information about the ages of rock, air or water bodies, or processes of mixing between them.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the ocean, including its physical, chemical, biologic, and geological aspects.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of the history and structure of the ocean floor. It involves geophysical, geochemical, sedimentological and paleontological investigations of the ocean floor and coastal zone.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of economically valuable minerals (ores) in the Earth's crust, including their formation, distribution, and extraction methods.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The microscopic study of metallic ores using reflected light.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Castroviejo, R 2023, A practical guide to ore microscopy—Volume 1: mineral identification, Springer International Publishing: Cham, Switzerland, 980p., doi.10.1007/978-3-031-12654-3.

definition.en: That branch of geology dealing with the description and systematic classification of rocks and especially by means of microscopic examination of thin sections. Petrography is more restricted in scope than petrology and overlaps considerably with mineralogy.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The branch of petrology that describes the composition, characteristics, textures, occurrence and origin of ore minerals, i.e. of naturally occurring minerals that contain valuable elements or minerals in sufficient quantities to be economically mined and processed for their desired metal or mineral content.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from https://geologyscience.com/ore-genesis/ore-minerals/.

definition.en: Organic petrology involves the study of organic matter (OM) in rocks, including its origin and thermal maturity due to burial within the Earth's crust.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: That branch of paleontology that treats the geographic distribution of organisms in past geological time, especially with regard to the ecologic, climatologic, and evolutionary factors involved. It includes the more specialized paleophytogeography and paleozoogeography subdisciplines.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of plants, fungi and algae from geological contexts, and their use for the biological reconstruction of past environments (paleogeography), as well as the evolutionary history of plants and allied kingdoms, with a bearing upon the evolution of life in general. These fossils can be impressions or compressions of the plants left on the rock's surface, or 'petrified' objects, such as wood, which preserve the original plant material in rocklike form.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: A subdiscipline of paleontology concerned with reconstructing past biota, populations, communities, landscapes, environments, and ecosystems from available geological and biological (fossil) evidence. It encompasses the study of interactions between organisms and/or interactions between organisms and their environments across geological timescales, including reconstructions of past ecosystems and environments using this information.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Birks, HJB 2008, Palaeoecology, in Encyclopedia of Ecology, Academic Press, p. 2623–2634, doi:10.1016/B978-008045405-4.00525-5)
2) Wikipedia.

definition.en: The reconstruction of past environments and their climates within regions or across regions, based on the sediments, soils, strata, and associated biological remains.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Holliday, VT and Mandel, RD 2024, Paleoenvironmental Reconstruction, in Encyclopedia of Geoarchaeology, edited by AS Gilbert, P Goldberg, RD Mandel and V Aldeias, Encyclopedia of Earth Sciences Series: Springer, Cham. doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4020-4409-0_191.

definition.en: The study of climates prior to the period of instrumental records, and of the causes of their variation, on either a local, regional or worldwide basis. It uses a variety of proxy methods from the Earth and life sciences to obtain data preserved within rocks, sediments, ice sheets, tree rings, corals, shells, and microfossils to determine the past states of the Earth's various climate regions and its atmospheric system.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The dating of geological materials by comparing the magnetic signature in rocks to known changes in the Earth's magnetic field (based on movements of the magnetic north pole over geological time). It is based on matching the changes in the paleomagnetic field recorded in lava flows or sediments with their corresponding dates in the magnetic polarity time scale. When applied to archeology, it is referred to as archeomagnetics.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials (rocks, sediments and archeological materials) in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Originally, the study of pollen and spores, extant and fossil (paleopalynology), including stratigraphic and paleoecological applications. Now includes the study of a wide range of other robust-walled, acid-insoluble microscopic remains of various plants, animals, fungal spores and protists, including kerogen and unidentifiable organic matter.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Traverse, A 2008, Paleopalynology: Springer, Dordrecht, The Netherlands, 813p.

definition.en: The systematic study of microfossils (i.e. fossils too small to be observed without the aid of a microscope), their morphology, classification, and environmental and biostratigraphic significance. Microfossils can represent the remains, or partial remains, of a wide range of organism kingdoms and phyla, but palynomorphs are generally excluded.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Saraswati, PK and Srinivasan, MS 2015, Micropaleontology: principles and applications: Springer Cham, 224p., doi.10.1007/978-3-319-14574-7.

definition.en: The detection of natural low frequency earth movements, commonly with the purpose of discerning geological structures and locating underground oil, gas, or other resources.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: One of the disciplines of soil science, pedology is the study of soil morphology, genesis, and classification. Pedometrics specifically refers to the use of quantitative methods for the study of soil distribution and genesis.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The science dealing with soils as a natural resource on the surface of the Earth including (a) soil formation, soil classification and mapping; (b) physical, chemical, biological, and fertility properties of soils per se; and (c) these properties in relation to the use and management of soils.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The fields of engineering concerned with activities related to the production of hydrocarbons to determine the way in which a reservoir is developed and depleted, i.e. the study and application of scientific and engineering principles to the fluid flow through a porous medium during the development and production of oil and gas reservoirs so as to obtain a high economic recovery.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The characterization of the physical properties and elemental analysis of oil and gas, used to interpret the type of source rock and correlate to a source rock, determine the thermal maturity of the oil and gas (and hence the maturity of the source rock), potential dating of the source rock, and compare oil and gas composition between different fields or within a field.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

definition.en: The study of the role of processes and compounds that are derived from living or once-living organisms, i.e. the study of the transformation undergone by organic matter of all types, whether of biological or man-made origin, in the Earth System. The transformations involved vary from those mediated by biological processes involved in the production of living tissue and the operation of food-chains, to those controlled by temperature and pressure at depth in the crust. Photochemical processes in the atmosphere and hydrosphere can also be important in controlling the environmental behaviour of some organic compounds.

historyNote.none:
From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from: 
Killops, SD and Killops, VJ 2013, Introduction to Organic Geochemistry: John Wiley & Sons, 408p.

definition.en: An approach to systematics (the study of the kinds and diversity of organisms and the relationships between them) that attempts to recover the phylogenetic (genealogical) relationships among groups of organisms, and produces classifications that reflect exactly those genealogical relationships.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Evolutionary paleontology (also called evolutionary paleobiology) is paleontology’s intersection with evolutionary biology. Its main aims are to reconstruct the history of life on Earth (historical paleontology, phylogeny) and the patterns and causes of evolutionary change and extinction (biological and physical processes and unique historical events).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from https://www.eolss.net/sample-chapters/c01/e6-15-04-04.pdf.

prefLabel.en: physical geography and environmental geoscience not elsewhere classified

definition.en: Physical geographical and environmental science data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of physical geography.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: Public administration is the planning, preparation, and execution of policy meant to build and strengthen civil society. Policy, in this context, refers to prudence or wisdom in the management of affairs, or management procedures based primarily on material interest.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from the Merriam-Webster dictionary.

definition.en: The study of a group of individuals involved in persistent social interaction or of a large social group sharing the same spatial or social territory, typically subject to the same political authority and dominant cultural expectations.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The field search for valuable commodities, mineral specimens (e.g. gold nuggets, crystals), lapidary material, and mineral deposits — usually with the ultimate objective of economic development by mining operations. Prospectors may be divided into two general categories: those with academic, scientific training and those with only field training or in the purely amateur category.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Fairbridge, RW 1988, Prospecting, in General Geology, Encyclopedia of Earth Science: Springer, Boston, MA, doi.10.1007/0-387-30844-X_93.

definition.en: A predictive tool typically used for mineral exploration targeting at the broad regional- to camp-scale. It is less effective and less frequently used at the project- to deposit-scale where predictive tools compete with direct detection techniques. It includes the delineation of prospective areas based on personal experience and interpretation of available geological, geochemical and geophysical data, as well as statistical data analysis/modelling, and in combination GIS-based spatial datasets and/or soft computational models (e.g. fuzzy logic).

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Porwal, AK and Kreuzer, OP 2010, Introduction to the Special Issue: Mineral prospectivity analysis and quantitative resource estimation: Ore Geology Reviews, v. 38(3), p. 121-127, doi:10.1016/j.oregeorev.2010.06.002.

definition.en: A discipline focused on the quantitative measurements of the mineralogy, chemistry, morphology and microstructures of minerals and mineral assemblages using a range of analytical techniques (e.g. modal analysis, X-ray diffractometry, infrared and Raman spectroscopy, refractometry, spectral mapping, etc.). Specifically, quantitative mineral methodologies are utilized to measure and/or constrain mineral abundances, as well as to provide mineral grade and texture information for geological and mineral processing applications.

historyNote.none:
Definition from:
Keulen, N, Malkki, SN and Graham, S 2020, Automated Quantitative Mineralogy Applied to Metamorphic Rocks, in Applications of SEM Automated Mineralogy: From Ore Deposits over Processing to Secondary Resource Characterization), edited by B Schulz: Minerals, v.10(1), 47, doi:10.3390/min10010047.

definition.en: The study of industrial mineral resources, i.e. geological materials that are mined/quarried for their commercial value and are not fuel (fuel minerals or mineral fuels) or sources of metals (metallic minerals) but are used in their natural state or after beneficiation either as raw materials or as additives in a wide range of applications based on their physical and/or chemical properties. These studies include the quantification of the physical properties, chemical properties, volumes, and limitations to development of quarry products. Quarry resources (also referred to as basic raw materials or industrial minerals) include, but may not be limited to, sand (including silica sand), clay, hard rock (including dimension stone), limestone (including metallurgical limestone), agricultural lime, gravel, gypsum, other construction and road building materials and materials which may substitute these raw materials.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of western Australia.

definition.en: The branch of geology that study environmental changes from 2.58 million years ago to the present. In particular, Quaternary geology study the process and deposits that developed during the Quaternary, a period characterized by glacial–interglacial cycles.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The dating of geological materials by using the effects of radioactivity other than the natural decay from a parent to a daughter isotope. It includes methods such as fission tracks (measure of the density of track marking left in a material by the spontaneous fission of uranium-238 impurities), luminescence (measure of the effect of background radiation on certain minerals), and electron spin resonance (ESR), measure of the amount of unpaired electrons in crystalline structures that were previously exposed to natural radiation). The term radiogenic here is used as in Colman et al. (1987).

historyNote.none:
Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition based on:
Colman, SM, Pierce, KL and Birkeland, PW 1987, Suggested terminology for Quaternary dating methods: Quaternary Research, v. 28(2), p. 314–319, doi:10.1016/0033-5894(87)90070-6.

definition.en: The branch of isotope geochemistry focusing on radiogenic isotope systems, i.e. those where a daughter isotope is produced from the decay of a radioactive parent isotope.

historyNote.none:
Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from:
Banner, YL 2004, Radiogenic isotopes: systematics and applications to earth surface processes and chemical stratigraphy: Earth-Science Reviews, v. 65(3–4), p. 141–194, ISSN 0012-8252, doi:10.1016/S0012-8252(03)00086-2.

definition.en: The branch of geochronology / isotope geochemistry focusing on radiogenic isotope systems, i.e. those where a daughter isotope is produced from the decay of a radioactive parent isotope, to determine the numerical age of suitable geological materials.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Banner, YL 2004, Radiogenic isotopes: systematics and applications to earth surface processes and chemical stratigraphy: Earth Science Reviews, v. 65(3–4), p. 141–194, doi:10.1016/S0012-8252(03)00086-2.

definition.en: The radiometric, or gamma-ray spectrometric method is a geophysical process used to estimate concentrations of the radioelements potassium, uranium and thorium in the near surface.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Geoscience Australia website.

definition.en: The geological study of large-scale regions, providing a link between global and local geology, and a framework for site-specific studies.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from: 
Roberts, DG and Bally, AW (Eds), 2012, Regional Geology and Tectonics: Phanerozoic Rift Systems and Sedimentary Basins: Elsevier, 528p., doi.10.1016/B978-0-444-56356-9.00019-5.

definition.en: The mineralogical study of specific geographic regions, from ore deposits clusters to large metallogenic provinces. It includes evaluation of location and the spatial distribution of minerals and mineral assemblages in relation to the geological history of the province (region) or the formation of the deposit. Regional mineralogy can include mineral regional fingerprinting, and directly links to metallogeny and genetic mineralogy.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia based on the Lomonosov-Fund website from Moscow State University.

definition.en: The study of the geology of surficial deposits, i.e. those at or near the Earth's surface. It includes the study of soils and unconsolidated sediments, their geological features and structures, and their relationships to the underlying bedrock.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The stage in the life-cycle of a project or mine where the resources have been extracted and the site or part thereof is being rehabilitated back to its original condition or an acceptable environmental standard.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Geological Survey of Queensland Site status vocabulary.

definition.en: Environmental resource management or environmental management is the management of the interaction and impact of human societies on the environment (and not the management of the environment itself).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Geoscience studies related to the definition and exploitation of energy derived from natural resources such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat, that are replenished either through natural reproduction or other recurring processes in a finite amount of time on a human time scale.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: A characterization of a reservoir that incorporates all the characteristics of the reservoir that are pertinent to its ability to store hydrocarbons and also to produce them. Reservoir characterization models are used to simulate the behaviour of the fluids within the reservoir under different sets of circumstances and to find the optimal production techniques that will maximize the production. Typically, a reservoir analysis incorporates interpretation of depositional facies and diagenesis, mineralogical and textural maturity parameters obtained from macro/meso (e.g. cores, sidewall cores, cuttings) and micro (e.g. thin sections, scanning electron microscope work) samples, as well as direct and indirect measurements of porosity, permeability and grain density from well log analysis and core and mechanical sidewall cores. Image logs are used to determine fracture density where applicable. Regional reservoir distribution and thickness is derived from multiple well reservoir data, seismic interpretation and depth mapping.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and AAPG Wiki (https://wiki.aapg.org/).

definition.en: A theoretical and applied science of the physical behaviour of rocks and rock masses. In relation to geology, it is the branch of mechanics concerned with the response of rock and rock masses to the force fields of their physical environment.

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The study of the physical and mechanical properties of rocks. Petrophysics focuses on how the microstructure of porous geological materials affects their mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid flow, and sonic properties. Rock mechanics considers the mechanical or geomechanical properties of rocks, including reservoir strength, elastic properties, hardness, ultrasonic behaviour, index characteristics, and in situ stresses.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The use of satellites to determine the location (geographic position) of a receiver on Earth. The technique involves measuring the range between the receiver and the satellite, and the range measurement used to calculate the receiver's position using observation equations and least squares. The technique is used in global and regional satellite navigation systems.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition compiled from multiple sources.

definition.en: Remotely sensed spectral imaging obtained from a platform in orbit outside the atmosphere of Earth.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: A characterization of regional caprocks and intraformational barriers (seals) to understand their capacity to trap fluids (oil, gas, etc.); specifically to determine seal capacity (i.e. the capillary pressure, or column height, at which a trapped fluid commences to leak through a seal rock) and conduct fault seal analysis (a measure of the capacity of a fault to leak or seal hydrocarbons).

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Daniel, RF and Kaldi, G 2008, Evaluating seal capacity of caprocks and intraformational barriers for the geosequestration of CO₂: Abstracts for the PESA Eastern Australian Basins Symposium III, Sydney, 14–17 September 2008, p. 475.

definition.en: The study of the composition, characteristics, occurrence, and origin of sediments and sedimentary rocks.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The scientific study of sedimentary rocks and of the processes by which they were formed; the description, classification, origin, and interpretation of sediments.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

definition.en: The study of stratigraphy and depositional facies as interpreted from seismic data; an integrated stratigraphic and sedimentologic technique to interpret seismic reflection data for stratigraphic correlation and to predict depositional environments and lithology.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: Seismic tomography is a technique for imaging the subsurface of the Earth with seismic waves produced by controlled ‘active’ sources such as vibrations or explosions, or natural ‘passive’ sources such as earthquakes, wind, waves or human activity. P-, S-, and surface waves can be used for tomographic models of different resolutions based on seismic wavelength, wave source distance, and the seismograph array coverage. The data received at seismometers are used to solve an inverse problem, wherein the locations of reflection and refraction of the wave paths are determined. This solution can be used to create 3D images of velocity anomalies which may be interpreted as structural, thermal, or compositional variations.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The study of rock relationships within a chronostratigraphic framework of repetitive, genetically related strata bounded by surfaces of erosion or nondeposition, or their correlative conformities (Van Wagoner et al., 1990). Specifically, a field of study in which basin-filling sedimentary deposits, called sequences, are interpreted in a framework of eustasy, sedimentation and subsidence through time in order to correlate strata and predict the stratigraphy of relatively unknown areas.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary.

definition.en: The study of the chemical composition of the unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the surface of the earth that serves as a natural medium for the growth of land plants, and whose formation is conditioned by relief and controlled by genetic and environmental factors such as climate (including water and temperature effects) and biological activity (macro- and micro-organisms) acting on parent material over a period of time.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of the chemical composition of materials and components making up the surficial, weathered, and usually unconsolidated layer that nearly everywhere forms the surface of the land and overlies or covers the bedrock. Regolith includes rock debris of all kinds, volcanic ash, glacial drift, alluvium, loess and eolian deposits, vegetal accumulations, and soil.

historyNote.none: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The evaluation of the lithological sources of hydrocarbons, i.e. those rocks which contain organic matter and are (or have been) generating and/or expelling hydrocarbons to form accumulations.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from https://wiki.aapg.org/Source_rock.

definition.en: The exploration and scientific study of caves and other karst features, both physical and biological, including their composition and mineralogy, structure (morphology), physical properties, history, ecology, and the processes by which they form (speleogenesis) and change over time (speleomorphology).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

definition.en: The branch of geology that deals with the form (geometry), spatial arrangement, and internal structure of the rocks, and especially with the description, representation, and analysis of structures (e.g. bedding, folds, faults and fractures), chiefly on a meso- to macroscopic scale. The subject is similar to tectonics, but the latter is generally used for the broader regional or historical phases.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011) and Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary.

definition.en: The branches of geology that, combined, focus on the manifestation of plate tectonic motions in the deformation of Earth's crust and lithosphere, from the scale of mountain ranges to individual faults and folds, and on timescales from deep Earth history to present-day tectonism and associated natural hazards.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from: https://epsci.stanford.edu/structural-geology-tectonics-geomechanics.

definition.en: The study of the form, physical properties, composition, function, and evolution of Earth’s surface, a dynamic interface where physical, chemical, biological, and human processes cause and are affected by forces in the Earth system, with impact-feedback loops that occur over a wide range of temporal and spatial scales.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
National Research Council, 2010, 1 The Importance of Earth Surface Processes, Landscapes on the Edge: New Horizons for Research on Earth's Surface, Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. doi: 10.17226/12700.

definition.en: The subfield of hydrology concerned with above-earth water, in contrast to groundwater hydrology that deals with water below the surface of the Earth. Its applications include rainfall and runoff, the routes that surface water takes (for example through rivers or reservoirs), and the occurrence of floods and droughts.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The applied science of determining the two-dimensional or three-dimensional positions of points necessary to determine the area of any part of the Earth's (or other planetary body) surface, the lengths and directions of the boundary lines, and the contour of the surface, and of accurately delineating the whole on paper/digitally.

historyNote.none: Adapted from the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The branch of paleontology concerned with all processes occurring after the death of an organism until its discovery. It includes biostratonomy and fossil diagenesis.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
Behrensmeyer, AK and Kidwell, SM 1985, Taphonomy's contributions to paleobiology: Paleobiology, v. 11(1), p. 105-119, http://www.jstor.org/stable/2400427.

definition.en: The theory and practice of identifying, describing, naming, and classifying organisms. The terms taxonomy and systematics are usually distinguished, the latter having broader connotation, but they may also be used more or less synonymously.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The collection, preparation, petrographic description, and approximate dating of tephra. The technique uses discrete layers of tephra (volcanic ash from a single eruption) to create a chronological framework in which paleoenvironmental or archeological records can be placed. The premise of the technique is that each volcanic event produces ash with a unique chemical 'fingerprint' that allows the deposit to be identified across the area affected by fallout. Thus, once the volcanic event has been independently dated, the tephra horizon will act as time marker (as such it is a variant of the basic geological technique of stratigraphy).

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The study of the thermal evolution of a region of a planet. Thermochronologists use radiometric dating (the determination of the age of a sample based on the rate of decay of a radioactive nuclide) along with closure temperatures (i.e. the temperature of the mineral being studied at the time given by the date recorded) to understand the thermal history of a specific rock, mineral, or geological unit.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The geological study of unconventional petroleum systems, which comprise formations with tight gas, tight oil, oil sands, oil shale, bitumen, gas shales, coal seam gas/coalbed methane, and gas hydrates, and are defined as those where petroleum is distributed throughout the reservoir at basin-wide scale and in which buoyant forces or the influence of a water column on the location of hydrocarbons in the reservoir are not significant.

historyNote.none: Definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The application of geological knowledge and principles to the planning and management of cities and their surroundings. It includes geological studies for physical planning, waste disposal, land use, water-resources management, and extraction of usable raw materials.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: A multidisciplinary, applied science concerned with the practical application of the principles of geology in the solving of environmental problems created by humans and their activities. Environmental geology is specifically concerned with Earth processes, Earth resources, and engineering properties of Earth materials that are relevant to: 1) the protection of human health and natural ecosystems from adverse biochemical and/or geochemical reactions to naturally occurring chemicals or to chemicals and chemical compounds released into the environment by human activities; and 2) the protection of life, safety, and well-being human from natural processes, such as floods, hurricanes, earthquakes and landslides, through land-use planning.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: A dating method that utilizes the seasonal (summer and winter) sedimentological variations of deposits in lakes that undergo an annual freeze-up, by counting and measuring thicknesses in annual paired layers of sediments. Because each year’s sediment accumulation varies in thickness according to the climatic conditions of the melt season, any long sequence of varve measurements provides a distinctive 'signature' and can be correlated for moderate distances from lake basin to lake basin. Counting and correlation of varves have been used to measure the ages of Pleistocene glacial deposits.

historyNote.none:
Definition adapted from:
1) Mörner , N-A (ed.), 2014, Geochronology - Methods and Case Studies: InTech, doi:10.5772/57041
2) Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

definition.en: The branch of paleontology that studies the morphologic, taxonomic, systematic, stratigraphic, and biogeographic characteristics of Phylum Chordata. This includes modern vertebrates, non-vertebrate chordates (such as lancets and turnicates), and extinct groups of uncertain placement (such as conodonts).

historyNote.none: Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

definition.en: The branch of geology that deals with volcanism (e.g. volcanoes, lava, magma), its causes and related geological, geophysical and geochemical phenomena.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The systematic study of the inorganic world, as distinct from the study of the organic world, which is the province of biological science. Physical science is ordinarily thought of as consisting of four broad areas: astronomy, physics, chemistry, and the Earth sciences. Each of these is in turn divided into fields and subfields.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from www.britannica.com.

definition.en: The study of the Earth's atmosphere and its various inner-working physical processes.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020); definition from Geological Survey of Queensland Earth science data category vocabulary.

definition.en: The element of stratigraphy that deals with the distribution of fossils in the stratigraphic record and the organization of strata into units on the basis of their contained fossils, specifically to date and correlate strata to elucidate Earth's history. In the petroleum industry, biostratigraphy often denotes the use of terrestrial (pollen and spores) and marine (diatoms, foraminifera, nanofossils) microfossils to determine the numerical or relative age and depositional environment of a particular formation, source rock, or reservoir of interest.

historyNote.none: Definition adapted from Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf, 2011).

definition.en: Built environment refers to human-made conditions and physical features, and is commonly used in architecture, landscape architecture, urban and regional planning, public health, sociology, and anthropology, among others. These curated spaces provide the setting for human activity and were created to fulfill human desires and needs. The term can refer to a plethora of components including the traditionally associated buildings, cities, public infrastructure, transportation, open space, as well as more conceptual components like farmlands, dammed rivers, wildlife management, and even domesticated animals. Studies of the built environment often highlight the connection between physical space and social consequences. It impacts the environment and how society physically manoeuvers and functions, as well as less tangible aspects of society such as socioeconomic inequity and health.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: Urban planning, also known as town planning, city planning, regional planning, or rural planning in specific contexts, is a technical and political process that is focused on the development and design of land use and the built environment, including air, water, and the infrastructure passing into and out of urban areas, such as transportation, communications, and distribution networks, and their accessibility. Traditionally, urban planning followed a top-down approach in master planning the physical layout of human settlements, with a primary focus on public welfare (i.e. considerations of efficiency, sanitation, protection and use of the environment) as well as effects of the master plans on the social and economic activities. Over time, urban planning's focus has shifted to social and environmental factors to be a tool to improve the health and well-being of people while maintaining sustainability standards.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

definition.en: The science and technology of collecting/measuring, processing, analysing and interpreting information from noncontact imaging and other sensor systems that record the interaction between electromagnetic energy and matter, i.e. the acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon by using a recording device that is not in physical contact with the subject being studied. Aerial photographs and imagery acquired from a satellite or drone are examples of remotely sensed information.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

definition.en: The scientific study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves both natural and artificially generated through the Earth or through other planetary bodies. The field also includes studies of earthquake environmental effects such as tsunamis as well as diverse seismic sources such as volcanic, tectonic, oceanic, atmospheric, and artificial processes such as explosions. Seismic exploration is a method of exploration geophysics that uses the principles of seismology to estimate the properties of the Earth's subsurface from artificially generated seismic waves.

historyNote.none: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).
